title: Julio Gómez (footballer, born 1994)
text:
Julio Enrique Gómez González (born 13 August 1994), also known as "La Momia", is a Mexican professional <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> who plays as a <a href="Winger%20%28association%20football%29">winger</a>.
Club career.
Pachuca.
Julio Gomez (La Momia) made his debut for <a href="Pachuca">CF Pachuca</a> against <a href="Santos%20Laguna">Santos Laguna</a> in January 2011, in a game of <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Mexican%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20season%23Torneo%20Clausura">2011 Clausura</a> He was then loaned to Correcaminos and scored 13 goals in Clausura 2015. He was declared MVP by Correcaminos. Then Pachuca loaned him to <a href="Cafetaleros%20de%20Tapachula">Cafetaleros de Tapachula</a> for the 2015–16 season.
International career.
2011 FIFA U-17 World Cup.
Gómez was a regular starter in <a href="Mexico%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Mexico's</a> squad. In the second match against Congo; Gómez scored one of the two goals from Mexico.
In the semifinal match against <a href="Germany%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Germany</a> he scored two goals, the first of them in the third minute. In the play that derived in the second goal for Mexico, an by <a href="Jonathan%20Espericueta">Jonathan Espericueta</a>, Gomez's head collided with <a href="Samed%20Ye%C5%9Fil">Samed Yeşil</a>'s, after which he was left lying on the field, bleeding heavily. With no substitutions left, he returned to the field and scored the winning goal with a memorable <a href="bicycle%20kick">bicycle kick</a> in the last minutes of the match, and gave Mexico the pass to the final against <a href="Uruguay%20national%20under-17%20football%20team">Uruguay</a>.
He was not a starter in the final. However, he entered the game in the 80th minute, receiving a standing ovation from the fans. Mexico ended up defeating Uruguay 2–0, winning the championship.
Gómez was awarded the <a href="FIFA%20U-17%20World%20Cup%23Awards">Golden Ball</a> of the tournament. In total, he scored three goals, and participated in all seven games - six as starter, and as a substitute in the final.
Honours.
Mexico U17
Mexico U20
Individual
